Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the parent needs to handle the situation
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Story: I was standing in the checkout line, my son fidgeting beside me, when I noticed the crumpled candy wrapper peeking from his pocket. My heart sank. As a parent, I knew I had to teach him right from wrong, to show him that stealing—even something small—was unacceptable. I could already imagine the difficult conversation, the embarrassment, and the lesson I needed to impart. Just as I was gathering my thoughts, my phone buzzed. It was Mark, an old acquaintance from work, texting, “Hey, I’m in your neighborhood! Any good restaurant recommendations?” I knew he expected a quick, friendly reply, maybe even a bit of conversation. But my mind was spinning, torn between the urgent need to address my son’s behavior and the social expectation to be helpful and responsive. I felt the pressure mounting, my fingers hovering over my phone, my son’s guilty eyes on me, and the cashier calling for the next customer.
